medium: Shino ware; stoneware with underglaze iron
title: Square Bowl
text: During the sixteenth century, the potters of Mino, near Nagoya, developed a number of new ceramic styles for use in the tea ceremony. <I>Shino<I> ware was characterized by a thick, snowy surface which resulted from a feldspathic glaze fired for an extended period. <I>Shino<I> potters decorated their works by painting simple designs on the surface of the clay with iron-oxide slip prior to glazing. After firing, the resulting patterns shone softly through the milky glaze, producing a pleasingly subtle effect. Bowls such as this would have been used in the formal <I>kaiseki<I> meal as part of an extended tea ceremony.
description: shallow stoneware bowl of rounded rectangular form, four feet; decorated with an underglaze iron oxide pattern of hanging vines and fruit which appear grey and russet under the finely crackled, milky white shino glaze
